author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Scrutinizes Swiss Currency Practices
description: The Treasury Department declined to label any country a currency manipulator, but singled out Switzerland as an offender in its semiannual foreign exchange report.
content: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department said on Friday that it was concerned that some of America’s trading partners were taking actions to weaken their currencies and gain unfair trade advantages against the United States — but declined to label any country a currency manipulator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Pete Aguilar: A top messaging official was drafted for the inquiry.
description: Drafted for the committee by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Mr. Aguilar has risen to become vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus and the highest-ranking Latino in Congress.
content: When Representative Pete Aguilar, Democrat of California, hears Republican critics argue that the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol does not serve a legitimate purpose, he bristles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Chee
title: It’s Not Just the Story of Drag in Brooklyn, It’s the Story of America
description: Nicole Pasulka’s new history of drag in Brooklyn, “How You Get Famous,” closely follows a handful of queens to explore the cultural and business evolution of the drag industry.
content: HOW YOU GET FAMOUS: Ten Years of Drag Madness in Brooklyn, by Nicole Pasulka
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner and Austin Considine
title: ‘The Wire’ in Five Scenes
description: Cast members look back at some of the HBO drama’s most pivotal moments 20 years after its premiere.
content: From its premiere in June 2002 to its final episode in March 2008, “The Wire” told a sweeping story of crime, punishment and institutional disintegration in Baltimore. It was the components of that saga — the people, the moments — that made it unforgettable, scenes depicting the human consequences of civic collapse as well as the occasional hard-won triumph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Let’s Forget Romance
description: “How does one fall in love? Wouldn’t one fall out of it?”
content: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “Singleness Is Not a Stigma,” Ife Olatona calls into question “the widespread assumption that everyone is better off in an exclusive, romantic relationship.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Sam Ezersky scrambles up a twisty Sunday puzzle.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Yeow, this puzzle is tough; at every turn, there’s a clue that looks incomprehensible and requires consideration to interpret, let alone to solve. I expect as much from Sam Ezersky, who has been on a streak of devilishly difficult weekend constructions for the daily and variety puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Mei Pickart
title: It’s Hard to Believe That China Is Moving Forward When You’re Trapped in Your Apartment
description: Recovering from this breach of public trust won’t be easy.
content: SHANGHAI — In late March, Shanghai’s government assured us that there would be no Covid lockdown. Our city, China’s largest and most vibrant, was far too important for that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Nick Quested: A documentary filmmaker who had embedded with the Proud Boys is now in the spotlight.
description: Mr. Quested began spending time with the Proud Boys after the election as part of a project meant to explore the increasing polarization and extremism in American politics.
content: As a documentary filmmaker, Nick Quested has made a career of telling other people’s stories — many of them under harsh conditions. Over the years, he has made films about soldiers under fire in Afghanistan and the inner workings of a Mexican drug cartel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Socialism Is Supposed to Be a Working-Class Movement. Why Isn’t It?
description: Bhaskar Sunkara explains the reasons for the progressive left’s setbacks in winning power — and elections — in America.
content: American socialists today find themselves in a tenuous position. Over the past decade, the left has become a powerful force in American politics. Bernie Sanders seriously contested two presidential primaries. Democratic socialists have won local, state and congressional races. Organizations like Democratic Socialists of America and socialist publications like Jacobin have become part of the political conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Caroline Edwards: The first Capitol Police officer injured in the riot has said, ‘I’ve never experienced anything like it.’
description: She was struck during an assault at a barricade at the base of Capitol Hill.
content: After Capitol Police Officer Caroline Edwards suffered a concussion during the mob attack on Congress on Jan. 6, 2021, she didn’t stay down long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Hot Priest? Definitely a ‘Handsome’ One.
description: Annalise Deal and Kevin Neil met for coffee to discuss becoming Episcopal priests. The spirit also moved them to start dating.
content: Neither Kevin Gordon Neil nor Annalise Brittany Deal were looking for romance when they were introduced by a mutual friend in February 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Rangers Cede Control of Conference Finals to the Lightning
description: New York has come back throughout the playoffs, and will have to again on Saturday in Tampa with the Lightning one win from a third consecutive trip to the Stanley Cup Finals.
content: Though they were facing the two-time defending champion Tampa Bay Lightning, and though they had needed seven games to advance from each of the first two rounds of the playoffs, the Rangers always had a trump card in their pocket: Fortress Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eugene Yelchin
title: Aliens Among Us
description: Liam Francis Walsh’s graphic novel “Red Scare” revisits a chapter in American history when the fear of being labeled a communist led to rampant conformism.
content: Liam Francis Walsh’s masterly graphic novel debut, “Red Scare,” takes place in the fictional town of Clinker’s Corners at the height of the Cold War, when most Americans believed communists had infiltrated their institutions and neighborhoods. Ironically, anyone with a different set of values was considered an enemy, bringing the American way of life dangerously close to the Soviet way of life. The fear of being accused of communist affiliation resulted in a conformist attitude that spread across American society. Outward “normalcy” became the only acceptable form of social behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: How to Avoid a City Pool for Only $150 a Day
description: Pools were once the great social unifier of New York. The current vogue for high-priced day passes at rooftop hotel pools changes the equation.
content: On a Sunday afternoon in midsummer “when everyone sits around saying ‘I drank too much last night,’” Neddy Merrill, the doomed protagonist of John Cheever’s seminal 1964 short story, “The Swimmer,” sets out to make his way across his patch of well-heeled suburbia by water, traveling from pool to pool in what becomes an act of haunting self-realization.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Bhaskar Sunkara
description: A conversation with the political writer Bhaskar Sunkara.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Bhaskar Sunkara. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Blood Tests That Detect Cancers Create Risks for Those Who Use Them
description: The tests screen for cancers that often go undetected, but they are expensive and some experts worry they could lead to unnecessary treatments without saving patients’ lives.
content: Jim Ford considers himself a lucky man: An experimental blood test found his pancreatic cancer when it was at an early stage. It is among the deadliest of all common cancers and is too often found too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Christine Chung
title: The major tourist draws of San Juan, and Miami-Dade and Honolulu counties, have become virus hot spots.
description: “Covid-19 hasn’t disappeared as much as our patience for precautions has,” said one public health expert.
content: The three sizable urban centers in the United States where the coronavirus is spreading fastest right now have something in common: They are major warm-weather tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: McDonald’s Is Back, Moscow Style, as Russian Economy Stumbles On
description: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
content: Yevgeny Shumilkin is going back to work on Sunday. To prepare, he pulled the familiar “M” off what had been his McDonald’s shirt and covered the “M” on his McDonald’s jacket with a Russian flag patch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How Journalists Wrestle With Covering Threats to Democracy
description: A new report challenges news outlets to provide richer, more urgent coverage of the rise of authoritarian movements in the United States and abroad.
content: The banner headline on Friday’s print edition of The New York Times was pretty direct:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Avoid Nasty Pool Germs This Summer
description: Some watering holes are riskier than others.
content: Our local water park opened over Memorial Day weekend, and of course the kids begged us to take them. My husband and I easily relented — we enjoy zipping down water slides on hot days, too — but it was as crowded as we’d ever seen it. Eyeing the wave pool as it teemed with sweaty adults and snot-encrusted kids, I couldn’t help but wonder what kinds of gross germs lurked in it. And what about other crowded pools and lakes in the summertime — are they more like cesspools than swimming pools?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation is expected to have remained elevated in May as gas, rent and other prices surged.
description: The government is expected to report on Friday that consumer prices climbed by 8.2 percent in the year through May, as inflation hovers near the fastest rate in four decades.
content: The government is expected to report on Friday that consumer prices climbed by 8.2 percent in the year through May, as inflation hovers near the fastest rate in four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: An ‘Ugly’ Inflation Report Upended Hopes That Price Gains Would Ease
description: Investors and economists had expected to see some moderation in inflation. Instead, prices accelerated again in May, delivering an unwanted surprise.
content: Friday’s inflation report delivered an unwanted surprise for the White House, Federal Reserve and investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Hugh Dancy Is Ready to Skate Again
description: The “ridiculously handsome” British actor stars in the revived “Law & Order” and a “Downton Abbey” film.
content: Hugh Dancy flew around the rink, gliding from one foot to the next atop the black matting. The wind tousled his hair, the pattern on his houndstooth blazer blurring as he picked up speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 1: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by June 17 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on June 28.
content: Our 13th Annual Summer Reading Contest begins!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Sped Up Again in May, Dashing Hopes for Relief
description: The Consumer Price Index picked up by 8.6 percent, as price increases climbed at the fastest pace in more than 40 years.
content: A surge in prices in May delivered a blow to President Biden and underscored the immense challenge facing the Federal Reserve as inflation, which many economists had expected to show signs of cooling, instead reaccelerated to climb at its fastest pace since late 1981.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: When a Night on the Town Means Drinking, Dancing and Death
description: In “Last Call at the Nightingale,” a fizzy detective novel set in Prohibition-era Manhattan, a champagne-soaked evening at a speakeasy ends in murder.
content: Vivian Kelly, the heroine of Katharine Schellman’s fizzy series debut, LAST CALL AT THE NIGHTINGALE (Minotaur, 312 pp., $27.99), longs for escape. It’s Manhattan, 1924, not long after women gained the right to vote and lost the right to drink alcohol. The Jazz Age giveth and taketh away, but Vivian, a seamstress with an adventurous streak, doesn’t know that yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: In the Club and the Clubhouse, a Coach Adds Some Flavor
description: His passion is playing percussion at salsa clubs, but Charlie Montoyo also thrives at his day job: managing the Toronto Blue Jays.
content: The salsa band was 45 minutes into their first set at Lula Lounge on a recent Saturday when Charlie Montoyo showed up at the front door. An owner of the music club spotted Montoyo and led him and his group to a table reserved for them closest to the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Lightning Win Third Straight and Push Rangers to the Brink
description: The Rangers’ first playoff loss at Madison Square Garden since the first round came at an inopportune time for the team, which will face elimination in Game 6 after taking a 2-0 series lead.
content: Mikhail Sergachev scored his second goal of the game with 1 minute 50 seconds remaining to break a tie and push the Lightning to a 3-1 victory over the Rangers on Thursday night that gave Tampa Bay a 3-2 lead in the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: What Supporters of Gun Rights Mean When They Talk About ‘Evil’
description: Christian theology teaches that societies — not just individuals — bear responsibility for evil.
content: Greg Abbott, the governor of Texas, began his news conference on the day of the Uvalde massacre not with policy but theology. He said, “Evil swept across Uvalde today. Anyone who shoots his grandmother in the face must have evil in his heart, but it is far more evil for someone to gun down little kids.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Nicholas Fandos
title: Republicans Caught Every Break in New York. Then Paladino Arrived.
description: The incendiary congressional candidacy of Carl Paladino has divided New York Republicans and now threatens to shake up party leadership.
content: For New York’s beleaguered Republican Party, all signs had been pointing for months toward 2022 being an exceptional year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Swapping Books Brings Katy Tur Closer to Her Mother
description: “It’s like getting a postcard from inside the other’s head without even having to talk about it,” says the NBC News correspondent, whose new book is “Rough Draft,” a memoir. “Because who wants to talk about it?”
content: John le Carré’s “A Perfect Spy” and “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy”; Zadie Smith’s “Grand Union”; Eve Babitz’s “Sex and Rage”; “A Short History of London,” by Simon Jenkins, “Discovering the News,” by Michael Schudson, and (for reasons I can’t quickly explain) “Stop Reading the News: A Manifesto for a Happier, Calmer and Wiser Life,” by Rolf Dobelli. I also have a copy of “Hotel Scarface,” a book by my friend Roben Farzad about an old drug dealer’s hangout in Miami that was, by coincidence, a hangout of my old retired drug dealer of a father-in-law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: How inflation became a global problem.
description: Factors that were expected to fade have become stubbornly entrenched.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has caused inflation to become stubbornly entrenched in countries around the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Not Just a Fence: The Story of a Stainless Steel Status Symbol
description: Like the white picket fence, the stainless steel fence — prevalent in New York neighborhoods densely populated by Asian homeowners — evokes a sense of making it, but it’s flashier.
content: On the residential streets of Flushing, Queens, and Sunset Park, Brooklyn, steel fences line almost every other house. They’re silver, sometimes embellished with gold, and they’re in striking contrast to the modest brick and vinyl-clad houses that they encircle, like a diamond necklace worn atop an old white T-shirt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: After a ‘Raucous’ Start, a ‘Miss Guided’ Proposal
description: When Paul Harris Jr. met Allison Strickman, he was a few beers deep and left her unimpressed. They reconnected months later, and their ensuing courtship culminated on a boat called “Miss Guided.”
content: Though Allison Leigh Strickman’s first impression of Paul Clinton Harris Jr. was memorable, it was for reasons that Mr. Harris might have preferred she forget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: On Their First Night Out, He Spilled His Guts
description: Bianca Chavez and Stefan Norgaard, both Stanford graduates, met at the start of college in 2011. Their first interaction outside of class was not exactly romantic.
content: If there was a registry for stupendously awful meet-cutes, the one between Bianca Larez Chavez and Stefan Peter Norgaard could certainly be included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: If You’re Looking for Thor, Check the Beach
description: His outrageous fastball may never come back, but Noah Syndergaard is enjoying his new life with the Los Angeles Angels, on and off the field.
content: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Those who vividly remember Noah Syndergaard on top of the mountain, hair flying and fastball sizzling, may not recognize the 2022 version of the man they called Thor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Jared and Ivanka, Without the Power or the Masks
description: In stark videotaped interviews, Ivanka Trump accepted the notion that there had been no fraud in the 2020 election. Jared Kushner complained that a White House counsel had been “whining.”
content: WASHINGTON — They were stripped of their White House backdrop, their power and their masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kiefner
title: Steph Curry Is Boosting Black Designers at the N.B.A. Finals
description: The Golden State fashion plate has made a point of wearing looks from independent labels during his “tunnel walks.”
content: As the Golden State Warriors and the Boston Celtics face off in the N.B.A. finals, each team’s players have been bringing their top game to the court — and their best looks to the tunnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu, Maria Cramer, Noah Weiland and Michael D. Shear
title: Test to Return to the U.S. by Air Will Be Dropped
description: In a move hailed by the travel industry, starting Sunday morning passengers will be able to board flights to the U.S. without a negative coronavirus test.
content: As coronavirus policies and masking rules around the world faded away in recent months, one major mandate remained in place: Travelers flying to the United States had to provide a negative test result before boarding their plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nicole Tung
title: ‘We Are Still in Shock’: A Month Trapped in a Basement by Russian Forces
description: More than 300 Ukrainians, 77 of them children, were imprisoned in a dank and airless school basement for nearly a month. Ten of them died.
content: YAHIDNE, Ukraine — More than two months after the residents of Yahidne kicked down the bolted basement door where the Russian army had held them hostage, the village is being rebuilt but the memories remain fresh — and deeply painful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Some Monarch Butterfly Populations Are Rising. Is It Enough to Save Them?
description: Not all scientists agree with the findings of a new study, which seem likely to fuel an ongoing debate about the threats the butterflies face.
content: Every autumn, swarms of migrating monarchs descend on the mountains of central Mexico. It is the final stop on a journey of thousands of miles, as the butterflies travel from their North American breeding grounds to their winter colonies, where they blanket fir trees. Visitors who time their trips correctly might find the air so thick with monarchs that they can hear the butterflies’ wings beating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert
title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Belmont Stakes?
description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert assess the contenders for the 154th Belmont Stakes on Saturday.
content: Rich Strike, the 80-1 shot ridden by Sonny Leon and trained by Eric Reed, mounted a furious and improbable rally to capture the 148th Kentucky Derby on May 7. He was not even in the field until another horse was scratched the day before the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Why It Matters That the Jan. 6 Hearings Put ‘a War Scene’ on Display
description: The spectacle is the message.
content: There is every reason to be skeptical, even cynical, about the effect and impact of the Jan. 6 hearings on the political landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Fitting Into His Schedule, Then Into Her Royal Family
description: Jamal Akil Robinson offered just 30 minutes for his first get-together with Edna Tafari Makonnen, an Ethiopian princess. When the meeting ran to an hour, he saw it as a good sign.
content: Edna Tafari Makonnen and Jamal Akil Robinson initially struggled to find equal social footing when they got together for coffee in February 2015. That she is royalty was not the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Lockdowns Protected Older People. But at What Cost to the Health of Young Adults?
description: Since the pandemic began, their rate of death from all causes has skyrocketed.
content: Covid-19 has killed mostly old people. But since the pandemic began, the rate of death from all causes for younger adults has risen by a bigger percentage than has the rate of death from all causes for old people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora
title: Behind Enemy Lines, Scouts Help Ukrainians Execute Deadly Strikes
description: A nascent insurgency made up of civilians or former soldiers provided information that aided Ukraine’s attack on two Russian bases, according to a senior Ukrainian military official.
content: While a lack of weapons, ammunition and equipment hampers the Ukrainian military, there are signs that a nascent partisan insurgency is growing in potency, allowing Ukrainian forces to deliver deadly strikes on Russian-controlled territory even in areas where it is dangerous and sometimes impossible to commit troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: In Alaska, 48 House candidates and a first-of-its-kind special election
description: Voters are taking part in a mail-only special election with an open primary. Former Gov. Sarah Palin and Santa Claus are on the ballot.
content: Voters in Alaska are taking part in a new type of election this weekend: one conducted entirely by mail, the first of its kind in the state’s history. And it will be an open primary, allowing people to pick from candidates of both parties — also new in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Crime and Political Punishment
description: Voters are justifiably upset, but they’ll probably support the wrong people.
content: Results from Tuesday’s primaries in California suggest that crime may be a big issue in the midterm elections. In San Francisco, a progressive prosecutor was ousted in a recall vote. In Los Angeles, a businessman and former Republican who has run for mayor on the promise to be a big crime fighter made a strong showing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Valery Ryumin, Who Set Endurance Record in Space, Dies at 82
description: A Soviet cosmonaut, he spent 362 days in flight on three missions. He returned 18 years later on a U.S. shuttle to the Mir space station.
content: Valery Ryumin, a Soviet tank commander who became a cosmonaut and spent more than a year in space, setting endurance records — and then, after 18 years, took another flight, this time on a U.S. space shuttle — died on Monday. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Hill
title: A Times documentary revealed the violent scope of the Jan. 6 attacks.
description: “Day of Rage,” a six-month investigation by The New York Times published last year, which analyzed thousands of videos filmed at the Capitol building during the Jan. 6 riot, serves as a useful primer for the ongoing Congressional hearings.
content: “Day of Rage,” a six-month investigation by The New York Times published last year, which analyzed thousands of videos filmed at the Capitol building during the Jan. 6 riot, serves as a useful primer for the ongoing Congressional hearings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ife Olatona
title: Singleness Is Not a Stigma
description: It’s time we stop privileging romantic connections over all others.
content: In Yoruba, my native language where I grew up in Nigeria, my first name means “love,” but I have yet to experience love, the romantic kind. I want to love, to be loved, to witness a shower of affection beyond declarations or a supposed responsibility, but I remain unmoored by the prospect of romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Food Export Bans in Asia Prompt Fears of More Protectionism
description: Restricted so far in the name of domestic food security: Indian wheat, Malaysian chicken and Indonesian cooking oil. Experts warn of unwanted consequences.
content: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine helped push global agricultural prices to soaring heights, some Asian governments restricted the export of products they viewed as essential to domestic food security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Klaus Mäkelä, 26, Takes Podium at Storied Concertgebouw Orchestra
description: The Finnish maestro, a rapidly rising star in classical music, has been named the new chief conductor of the 133-year-old Amsterdam ensemble.
content: Klaus Mäkelä, a 26-year-old Finnish maestro on a rapid rise, will be the next chief conductor of the storied Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra in Amsterdam, the ensemble announced on Friday, after a several-year search following the dismissal of Daniele Gatti over sexual assault allegations in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Running Low on Ammo
description: Ukraine is in short supply of ammunition needed to hold the line against Russia.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: ‘Soft’ Review: Young Black Men, Gently Pointed Toward Liberation
description: In Donja R. Love’s new play, an English teacher struggles against the penal system — and with his own guilt — to help students see a future beyond prison.
content: Black manhood is envisioned as a delicate garden full of blossoms and wilts in Donja R. Love’s compelling new play “Soft,” receiving its world premiere at MCC Theater in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Idaho City to Pay $11.7 Million to Man Wrongfully Convicted in 1996 Killing
description: Christopher Tapp spent 20 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. He was exonerated in 2019, and the person who really killed Angie Dodge, 18, of Idaho Falls, was sent to prison.
content: The city of Idaho Falls, Idaho, has agreed to pay $11.7 million to a man who spent 20 years in prison after he was wrongfully convicted of murdering an 18-year-old woman in 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Hawa’s Hip-Hop Journey from the Philharmonic to Fashion
description: The classically trained rapper has modeled for Telfar, Burberry and North Face.
content: Name: Hawa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: New MoMA PS1 Director Resigns
description: Kate Fowle, who arrived in 2019, said she would step down in July from the Long Island City museum. She offered no reason for her abrupt departure.
content: Kate Fowle, who became director of MoMA PS1 in 2019 and barely had the chance to lead the museum as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic, abruptly announced on Friday that she was stepping down as of July 15 from the museum in Long Island City, Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Gidwitz
title: Beauty and the Beasts
description: In Jo Rioux’s “The Golden Twine,” an orphan girl who lives among traveling merchants aspires to be a monster tamer.
content: During a book giveaway at my daughter’s school, shrieking children swarm tables of books: “Are you sure it’s free?” “I can just have it?” “This is the best day of my life!” (Actual quotes. I’m going to mark that last one down as hyperbole.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Ocasio-Cortez Turns a New York Brawl Into a National Democratic Proxy Battle
description: By endorsing her colleague’s primary challenger, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has escalated a skirmish rippling beyond New York.
content: Sean Patrick Maloney is a Democratic Party stalwart who declares himself a “practical, mainstream guy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: After a Political Storm, Gay Days Return to Disney
description: An L.G.B.T.Q. tradition at Disney World took on new significance this year, when Disney was ensnared in a heated cultural debate.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Last Friday evening, about 6,000 people — almost all of them gay men — poured into a Walt Disney World water park near Orlando, Fla. Each had spent $100 or more on tickets for a private, adults-only Pride bacchanal called Riptide. “For one night, Disney’s Typhoon Lagoon Water Park becomes entirely yours for the party of the year,” online ads had promised. “Be part of the magic!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Nancy Clark Reynolds, a Player in Reagan’s Washington, Dies at 94
description: A renowned political insider, she parlayed her connections to become one of the city’s most sought-after lobbyists in the 1980s.
content: Nancy Clark Reynolds, whose life as a Washington insider stretched from the 1930s, when she arrived as the daughter of a New Deal congressman, to her role as a confidante to Ronald Reagan and, finally, to her prominence as one of the city’s best-connected lobbyists in the 1980s, died on May 23 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Julee Cruise, Vocalist of ‘Twin Peaks’ Fame, Dies at 65
description: In projects for the director David Lynch, she brought an eerie, otherworldly style to “Falling” and other songs.
content: Julee Cruise, a singer who brought a memorably ethereal voice to the projects of the director David Lynch — most famously “Falling,” whose instrumental version was the theme for Mr. Lynch’s cult-favorite television show, “Twin Peaks” — died on Thursday in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: The committee’s first witnesses helped depict chaos and violence on the ground.
description: Caroline Edwards, a Capitol Police officer, and Nick Quested, a British documentarian, recounted scenes of furor and mayhem.
content: To help paint a portrait of the mayhem and cruelty that unfolded during the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, committee leaders introduced witnesses on Thursday who were caught in the crowd of rioters, and whose personal retelling of the day’s events helped underscore how violent the riot became.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Despite a ‘Microscope Incident,’ Two Med Students Match
description: After an awkward encounter in their first year at Harvard Medical School, Drs. Ginger Jiang and José Orozco got a second chance at a connection.
content: Drs. Ginger Yu Fei Jiang and José Miguel Orozco didn’t quite hit it off after they were accidentally assigned the same microscope in pathology class during their first year at Harvard Medical School in 2013.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘Sexual Justice’ and ‘Last Call’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: SEXUAL JUSTICE: Supporting Victims, Ensuring Due Process, and Resisting the Conservative Backlash, by Alexandra Brodsky. (Metropolitan, 336 pp., $18.99.) In the words of our reviewer, Michelle Goldberg, Brodsky’s treatise on handling sexual assault allegations is a “practical, lawyerly work” and a refreshing intervention into debates about standards of evidence and the protections that students should be afforded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A new study is the first to document likely cat-to-human virus transmission, but risks are low overall, experts say.
description: People are far more likely to give the virus to cats than cats are to pass it to humans, experts stress.
content: A veterinarian in Thailand likely contracted the coronavirus from an infected pet cat last year, researchers concluded in a new study. It is the first documented case of suspected cat-to-human transmission, although experts stress that the risk of cats infecting humans with the virus remains low overall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: The Kids (in New Hands) Are Still All Right
description: The student dancers looked good in Kids Dance, the performance troupe of Ballet Tech, which has passed from Eliot Feld to Dionne Figgins.
content: Eliot Feld was riding the subway when the car filled with a bunch of rambunctious kids on a field trip. The year was 1977, and Feld, a prominent choreographer, had an epiphany: not about how to escape, but how he might discover undeveloped dancers among children like those. The next year, he joined with the New York City Department of Education to start a dance training program for public school students, which eventually became a school for grades four to eight: Ballet Tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Bennie Thompson: The Jan. 6 committee chairman is a veteran lawmaker from a conservative state.
description: As the chairman of the nine-member panel, Mr. Thompson has been in charge of approving the committee’s subpoenas, authorizing more than 100 of them.
content: Representative Bennie Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi, wasn’t supposed to be in this position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Oklahoma’s Abortion Law Raises Questions About N.C.A.A.’s Softball World Series
description: The N.C.A.A. has restricted previous events in response to state lawmakers. It faces that test again in Oklahoma, where softball championships are a mainstay and a restrictive abortion ban recently became law.
content: OKLAHOMA CITY — Last Saturday, like many days here in early June, was a softball fiesta. The 13,100-seat stadium — burnished and bulked up by a $27.5 million renovation that added a second deck — was teeming with young pony-tailed fans from Alva to Ardmore, partisans in Oklahoma, Oklahoma State or Texas colors, and softball aficionados who make the yearly sojourn to the Women’s College World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Why the Hearings Matter
description: Even if the Jan. 6 attack will not become a unifying moment for the country.
content: The opportunity for the Jan. 6 attack to serve as a unifying moment for the country has already been lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Cheney says Scott Perry and other G.O.P. House members sought pardons.
description: The House committee suggested it had evidence that multiple House Republicans, including Representative Scott Perry of Pennsylvania, had sought presidential pardons after the Jan. 6 riot for their efforts to challenge and overturn the 2020 election.
content: The House committee suggested it had evidence that multiple House Republicans, including Representative Scott Perry of Pennsylvania, had sought presidential pardons after the Jan. 6 riot for their efforts to challenge and overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Dana Rubinstein
title: No New Money for Jail Officers and Police in $101 Billion N.Y.C. Budget
description: Helped by better-than-expected tax revenue, the spending plan reflects the tension between Mayor Eric Adams and the City Council over the issue of crime.
content: Mayor Eric Adams and New York’s City Council speaker, Adrienne Adams, said on Friday they had reached agreement on a $101 billion municipal budget that, among other things, excludes Mr. Adams’s proposals to significantly increase staffing levels at the city’s jails and slightly increase the Police Department’s budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Stonewall Jackson’s Name Fell Fast, and a Fury Quickly Followed
description: Removing the names of Confederate generals from schools in Shenandoah County, Va., was a response to racial justice protests. The community has been fighting about it ever since.
content: WOODSTOCK, Va. — It was getting late, well past 10 p.m., when the Shenandoah County School Board finally got around to the question that had been hanging over the county for two long and exhausting years. Should Stonewall Jackson return?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Chair Stalking Returns to Bryant Park as Midtown Begins to Perk Up
description: Despite the patchy way in which workers are going back to their offices, the heart of New York City is starting to resemble itself in some ways.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at the unevenness of R.T.O. — return to office — and what it means for New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tom Perrotta on the Return of Tracy Flick
description: Perrotta talks about “Tracy Flick Can’t Win,” and Ann Leary discusses “The Foundling.”
content: Few fictional characters in recent decades have been as intensely discussed as Tracy Flick. The ambitious teenage protagonist of Tom Perrotta’s novel “Election” (1998) and the ensuing film adaptation, starring Reese Witherspoon, has been reconsidered in recent years as misunderstood and unfairly maligned. On this week’s podcast, Perrotta talks about Tracy’s return in his new novel, “Tracy Flick Can’t Win.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Single Cigarettes in Canada Will Be Inscribed With Warning
description: Cigarette boxes and packaging in Canada are also expected to see an expanded list of health effects related to smoking.
content: TORONTO — Every individual cigarette sold in Canada will carry a warning message under the terms of a new federal regulation intended to curb smoking, especially among young people, the country’s minister of mental health and addictions announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Cockatoos Become Cocka-Too Much
description: The native Australian birds are charismatic and deeply destructive.
content: The Australia Letter is a weekly newsletter from our Australia bureau. Sign up here to receive it by email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: How Superworms Make Styrofoam Into a Healthy Meal
description: By understanding the microbes that help large beetle larvae digest polystyrene, scientists hope to find a better disposal process for packing foam.
content: The plump, glossy larvae of the darkling beetle, nicknamed “superworms” perhaps because of their size, are usually content to munch on wheat bran. But a number of the two-inch-long critters recently found themselves dining on much stranger fare in the service of science: polystyrene, the long-lived plastic packing material known sometimes by the brand name Styrofoam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: 5 Takeaways From the First Jan. 6 Hearing
description: The committee’s leaders laid out what they described as an intentional scheme with Donald J. Trump at the center. Videotaped testimony showed that key figures surrounding the president didn’t believe the lie of a stolen election.
content: The opening House hearing into the events surrounding the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was a compact and controlled two hours, designed as an overview of what was described as a methodical conspiracy, led and coordinated by President Donald J. Trump, to thwart the peaceful transfer of power and democracy itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Postpones Trip to Africa, Citing Knee Problems
description: The postponement of the trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan comes as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be thinking of stepping down.
content: ROME — The Vatican said Friday that Pope Francis would postpone a trip to Africa because of problems with his knee, an announcement that came as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be planning to follow in the steps of his predecessor and step down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Chile Loses Bid to Replace Ecuador at World Cup
description: Chile’s soccer federation had argued Ecuador should be ejected from the tournament for using an ineligible player in qualifying. FIFA disagreed.
content: Chile’s bid to have its South American rival Ecuador thrown out of soccer’s World Cup failed on Friday when a disciplinary panel at soccer’s global governing body rejected a claim that Ecuador had fielded an ineligible player in several qualification matches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: The committee hired a TV executive to produce the hearings for maximum impact.
description: It has brought on a veteran TV executive James Goldston to produce the hearings.
content: For almost a year, the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol has been painstakingly collecting interviews with 1,000 witnesses and producing over 140,000 documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Quince’ Review: A Mexican American Tale That Explains Too Much
description: The new play, about a 15-year-old girl and her impending quinceañera, creates a fitting party vibe. If only the script didn’t clarify every cultural reference.
content: In the backyard of a modest house with a thriving garden, a woman in a brimmed hat festooned with streamers bends over the flowers, tending to them silently. Her face a mask, she pays no attention to the pair of teenage sweethearts in the midst of a private talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Report Reveals Sharp Rise in Transgender Young People in the U.S.
description: New estimates based on C.D.C. health surveys point to a stark generational shift in the growth of the transgender population of the United States.
content: The number of young people who identify as transgender has nearly doubled in recent years, according to a new report that captures a stark generational shift and emerging societal embrace of a diversity of gender identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: SZA’s ‘Ctrl’ Bonus, and 8 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Saucy Santana, Demi Lovato, Joyce Manor and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Jan. 6 Hearing Put a True-Crime Drama on Prime-Time TV
description: The first night of the Jan. 6 hearings was serious public service, but it told an engrossing story with the tools of a limited series drama.
content: The first night of the congressional Jan. 6 hearings was not an entertainment. It was deadly serious reality, offering a panorama and a terrifying close-up of a real nightmare: The attempt, through violence, to effectively end American democracy by overturning the will of the voters and keeping President Donald J. Trump installed in an office that he lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Is Depicted as a Would-Be Autocrat Seeking to Hang Onto Power at All Costs
description: As the Jan. 6 committee outlined during its prime-time hearing, Donald J. Trump executed a seven-part conspiracy to overturn a free and fair democratic election.
content: In the entire 246-year history of the United States, there was surely never a more damning indictment presented against an American president than outlined on Thursday night in a cavernous congressional hearing room where the future of democracy felt on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Iraqi at Guantánamo Bay to Plead Guilty in Afghan War Crimes Case
description: Abd al-Hadi al-Iraqi, who is accused of leading forces that killed U.S. and allied troops, is disabled. A resolution of his case would involve finding a country to take him into custody.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A disabled Iraqi prisoner at Guantánamo Bay has reached an agreement with military prosecutors to plead guilty to war crimes charges related to his role as a commander of insurgent forces in Afghanistan in the early 2000s, lawyers disclosed in court Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charity Robey
title: The Johnny Appleseed of Sugar Kelp
description: The quest of a Long Island seaweed farmer to make kelp the next kale.
content: When Michael Doall was a teenager, he hated seaweed, and so did everybody else he knew on Long Island. It was an icky nuisance that brushed against your legs at the beach, fouled your fishing hook and got tangled around the propeller of your boat. Only later, as a marine scientist and oyster farmer, did he develop a love for sugar kelp, a disappearing native species that is one of the most useful seaweeds. Now he is on a mission to bring it back to the waters of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden and Latin American Leaders Announce Migration Deal
description: President Biden is trying to confront repeated surges of migrants at the U.S. border by casting the issue as a problem for the entire region, not just the United States.
content: LOS ANGELES — President Biden and leaders of Latin American countries signed a new agreement on Friday to confront the consequences of mass migration, making specific numerical pledges to allow more people fleeing political and economic strife to cross their borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russia and Ukraine are struggling to control “dead cities.”
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the battle for Sievierodonetsk as a crucial moment in what is increasingly a war of attrition in eastern Ukraine. “The fate of our Donbas is being decided there,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A ‘Strange’ Wind Blowing: Tony Voters Like ‘Loop’ and ‘Lehman’
description: We surveyed voters ahead of this year’s ceremony on Sunday. They are strikingly split in the races for leading musical performers.
content: After a strange year on Broadway, it looks as if it could be a “Strange” night at the Tony Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: The Bumpy Road to a Group-Led Documenta
description: The 2022 edition of this exhibition in Germany is curated by a leaderless collective. Things didn’t always go to plan.
content: KASSEL, Germany — Every five years, the international art world descends on this orderly, prosperous city for Documenta, considered the world’s most important contemporary art exhibition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
title: What Is LIV Golf? It Depends Whom You Ask.
description: Bold new project or crass money grab? Even golf’s best players can’t agree on the new Saudi-financed golf tour. Here’s what you need to know.
content: The new Saudi-financed, controversy-trailed LIV Golf series, which is holding its first event this week at an exclusive club north of London, is the talk of golf. Not always, though, in the ways its organizers had hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: For South Africa’s Leader, Being a Burglary Victim Spells Trouble
description: After a fortune in cash was stolen from President Cyril Ramaphosa’s farmhouse, he kept it secret. Now that word is out, critics ask what he was hiding.
content: CAPE TOWN — The burglars cut through a wire fence around the sprawling property, crept up to a stone farmhouse, climbed through a window and rifled through the furniture until they found their bounty: a fortune in U.S. dollars, in cash, said to be in the millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak
title: Shortage of Artillery Ammo Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
description: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
content: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Nearly four months after Russia invaded, the Ukrainian military is running low on ammunition for its Soviet-era artillery and has not received enough supplies from its allies to keep the Russians at bay, Ukrainian officials and artillery officers in the field say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Even a Powerful Queen First Must Survive Being a Teenager
description: “Becoming Elizabeth,” a new show on Starz, depicts Queen Elizabeth I’s early years, which are rarely seen onscreen, as a claustrophobic family drama.
content: LONDON — At the start of “Becoming Elizabeth,” a new Starz series about the little-depicted teenage years of Queen Elizabeth I of England, a carriage clatters through a rain-drenched dawn, led by riders on horseback bearing flaming torches. It is January 1547, and the carriage is carrying the body of King Henry VIII; immediately after, we see his legitimate children, Edward, Mary and Elizabeth, roused from bed and ushered through dark corridors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Dark Winds’ Review: Murder Most Foul in the Navajo Nation
description: A six-episode adaptation of Tony Hillerman’s tribal-police mysteries finally puts the invaluable actor Zahn McClarnon at the top of the cast list.
content: The natural way to lead a review of “Dark Winds,” which premieres Sunday on AMC, would be to note that it is a series written, directed and performed largely by Native Americans; set in the Navajo Nation and filmed on location in New Mexico; and bringing to screen the tribal police officers Joe Leaphorn and Jim Chee from Tony Hillerman’s best-selling mystery novels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Hits Back at Daughter’s Account That She Accepted His Election Loss
description: The former president, responding to videotaped testimony played at the Jan. 6 hearing, said Ivanka Trump had been “checked out” and was not involved in studying the election results.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald J. Trump, long known for distancing himself from or tossing aside staff members who contradicted him while he was in the White House, discovered a new target on Friday: his elder daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Lessons From Henry Ford About Today’s Supply Chain Mess
description: The automobile pioneer believed short-term interests must not squeeze out investment in a business’ resilience, a lesson many companies have learned the hard way since 2020.
content: DEARBORN, Mich. — Henry Ford, the godfather of mass production, was tormented by the possibility of running out of parts and raw materials. Suspicious of financiers — a spirit that animated his fervent antisemitism — he was especially distrustful of his suppliers. He was consumed with stockpiling enough materials to ensure that his assembly lines could continue operating without debilitating shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: A Conductor’s Tumultuous, Invaluable Tenure Ends in Minnesota
description: After 19 years, Osmo Vänskä is leaving a Minnesota Orchestra that once again stands proud after a nearly disastrous lockout.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Osmo Vänskä has said goodbye to the Minnesota Orchestra once before. But this time, it’s for real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: First-Pass Friday: The Only Way Out Is Through
description: It took me forever to break into Blake Slonecker’s puzzle, but it was worth it. The key is not giving up.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to another First-Pass Friday, the occasional column where I show you how I got my start in a New York Times crossword. More often than not, I actually show you how I didn’t get much of a start, because even someone who has solved crossword puzzles every day for the past decade can still completely miss the boat. If I do this correctly, you should feel reassured about your own solving. No, don’t thank me. I’m a giver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: In ‘The Baby,’ Killing With Cuteness
description: This British horror-comedy, which has its season finale on Sunday, literalizes the terrors of motherhood.
content: The British horror-comedy “The Baby” contains its fair share of blood, supernatural machinations and demonic possessions. Since its premiere in April on HBO, the limited series has delivered a steady stream of gore, grisly deaths and ghosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Lauren Herstik
title: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Present His Defense in Sex Assault Lawsuit
description: Judy Huth has accused Mr. Cosby of sexually assaulting her 47 years ago, when she was 16, but an expert witness for the defense testified that memories can become distorted over time.
content: Bill Cosby’s lawyers presented expert testimony about memory at a civil trial in California on Thursday as they tried to discredit a woman’s account of what she said was a sexual assault by Mr. Cosby some 47 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: In videotaped testimony, Barr dismissed Trump’s claims of fraud.
description: Trump’s last Senate-confirmed attorney general recalled how he had told the president he considered it “bullshit” and wanted no part of it.
content: Representative Bennie Thompson, Democrat of Mississippi, opened the hearing by calling the actions of former President Donald J. Trump an “attempted coup,” laying out starkly the threat that the country faced on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Recaps ‘Episode One’ of the Jan. 6 Hearings
description: He called the prime time congressional hearings “this summer’s most compelling drama.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Ali Watkins
title: Hoax Shooting Threats Rattle New York Schools
description: A tactic using social media sites to direct threats at individual students has unsettled schools in New York City and around the country.
content: A 14-year-old freshman at Murrow High School in Brooklyn was sitting in history class one April morning when she got a string of chilling texts from a friend. A threat to shoot up the school had been posted on the chat site Omegle — and it included a list of about a dozen students who would be killed. One of them was the 14-year-old girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Paula Rego, Artist Known for Unsettling Images, Dies at 87
description: Her paintings, many of which focused on women’s experiences and perspectives, might depict fear or menace. But it was up to the viewer to fill in the blanks.
content: Paula Rego, who in extraordinary artworks across 70 years could be menacing, unsettling, playful or all of those at once, her paintings suggesting macabre stories but inviting viewers to fill in the details, died on Wednesday at her home in North London. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Democrats Failed to Extend Assault Weapons Ban in 2004. They Regret It.
description: A push to renew the ban is so unlikely to succeed that one Democratic aide likened it to trying to jam the world’s biggest genie back into the world’s smallest bottle.
content: WASHINGTON — In late 1993, Democrats were on the cusp of a legislative triumph that seems inconceivable in today’s polarized debate over gun control: They were about to outlaw an entire class of firearms — semiautomatic assault rifles — as part of a big bipartisan crime bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: At Least 20 Million Watched Jan. 6 Hearing
description: The number is in the ballpark of big television events like a “Sunday Night Football” game.
content: An audience of at least 20 million people watched the first prime-time hearing of the House Select Committee’s investigation into the Jan. 6 attack on Thursday night, according to Nielsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: C.D.C. Dismisses Airborne Transmission of Monkeypox. Some Experts Disagree.
description: The virus “is not known to linger in the air,” agency officials said. But the research is far from definitive.
content: Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday pushed back against the idea that the monkeypox virus can spread through the air, saying the virus is usually transmitted through direct physical contact with sores or contaminated materials from a patient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Playwright and Memoirist Spends His Sundays
description: Every weekend, Alvin Eng revisits his past by strolling through Chinatown and the East Village.
content: The playwright and storyteller Alvin Eng grew up with five siblings in a house near the family’s business, the Foo J. Chin Chinese Hand Laundry in Flushing, Queens. Sunday, the only day the laundry was closed, was a big deal, as he recounts in his new memoir, “Our Laundry, Our Town: My Chinese American Life From Flushing to the Downtown Stage and Beyond.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Song Hae, Who Survived War and Poverty to Become a Beloved TV Host, Dies at 95
description: Born in what is now North Korea, he was known for his cheeky grin and folksy wisecracks as the host of South Korea’s weekly “National Singing Contest” for more than three decades.
content: SEOUL — Song Hae, who fled North Korea as a young man during the Korean War and became a beloved television personality in South Korea, recognized by Guinness World Records as the world’s “oldest TV music talent show host,” died on Wednesday at his home in here. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: It’s Rosé Season, but Drink These 12 Bottles Year-Round
description: There’s no reason to confine rosé to the summer, but for good reasons the season does have a special hold on the wines.
content: I don’t need to tell you that rosé season has begun. The bottles are crowding the seasonal displays in wine shops, the days are still growing longer and the get-it-done determination of the cooler months is giving way to a summer laxity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: A Chinese Entrepreneur Who Says What Others Only Think
description: Already a maverick in business circles, Zhou Hang has dared to openly criticize the government’s zero Covid policy — and urges his peers to speak out, too.
content: China’s entrepreneur class is grappling with the worst economic slump in decades as the government’s zero Covid policy has shut down cities and kept would-be customers at home. Yet they can’t seem to agree on how loudly they should complain — or even whether they should at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: We’ve Added More Songs to the California Soundtrack
description: Our never-ending pursuit for a playlist that perfectly captures the Golden State.
content: It’s Friday. We’ve added more of your picks to our Golden State playlist. Plus, triple-digit temperatures are expected in large swaths of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Ana Swanson
title: Biden Casts Inflation as a Global Problem During a Visit to the Port of Los Angeles
description: The visit to the nation’s busiest entry point for goods comes as President Biden struggles to show progress on resolving supply chain issues that are fueling inflation.
content: LOS ANGELES — President Biden on Friday defended his administration’s efforts to deal with inflation, just hours after a new report showed a surprise spike in prices that puts new pressure on the White House to ease the burden on consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are You Reading (or Watching or Listening to) That Has Given You an ‘Aha!’ Moment?
description: Tell us about the work and why it set off a light bulb.
content: Every Friday, the Interpreter newsletter — featuring original analysis on the week’s biggest global stories from the columnist Amanda Taub — includes an item that particularly caught Taub’s attention or sparked an “aha!” moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: John Waters, an Auteur of Trash, Would Like to Thank the Academy
description: Curators from the new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures rummaged through his Baltimore home to plan an exhibition on Waters and his cult films.
content: BALTIMORE — John Waters was leading a delegation from the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures — in for the week from Los Angeles — on a tour of his home of 32 years, cluttered with film artifacts and kitschy curios and tucked behind trees on a quiet corner five miles from this city’s waterfront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: A Single Image of Gun Violence Could Help Change Minds
description: Though grisly, showing what rifles do to people is a chance to finally shift the gun debate.
content: At a judges’ dinner this week for the Livingston Awards, aimed to honor the work of journalists under 35 years old, the older ink-stained wretches like myself talked about a range of things that were impacting the media business. That included the usual topics, like online misinformation. (In fact, the national award went to an astonishing series about that toxic and growing phenomena, including a family torn asunder by conspiracy theories, by Jose A. Del Real at The Washington Post.) Also on the docket, as always, the question of how to restore the American public’s trust in the reporters and the institutions they work for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Royal Shipwreck From 1682 Is Found Off the Coast of England
description: The Gloucester, which was carrying a future king of England when it ran aground, was found 15 years ago. Its discovery was revealed this week.
content: LONDON — The wreckage of a Royal Navy ship, from which a future king of England narrowly escaped when it sank 340 years ago during a period of political strife, was discovered off the country’s east coast, researchers said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Brought Together by Dance, and Undeterred by Distance
description: About a year after Drs. Maya Kailas and Amit Kohli met as members of a college dance team, they started dating and became “inseparable.” Then he graduated.
content: In July 2019, after six years of long-distance dating, Drs. Maya Kailas and Amit Kohli were finally in the same city. Yet even though they shared an apartment in Manhattan, they still faced similar struggles when it came to finding time to see each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Robert Lewandowski, Bayern Munich and the Bitter End
description: A star striker is eager to move to Barcelona, and his club doesn’t seem to realize it might be its own fault that he wants to go.
content: Robert Lewandowski does not, in his own words, like to make “too much show.” He is, and always has been, a touch more impassive than the average superstar. He does not greet his goals, the ones that have come for so long in such improbable quantities, with a roar, or a leap, or a scream. Instead, he grins. For the really good ones, he might go so far as a beam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Britney Spears: The Once and Future Versace Muse
description: The singer wore the Italian brand for her wedding to Sam Asghari, culminating a longstanding fashion relationship.
content: The dress was long. It was white. It was Versace. And it wasn’t just a wedding dress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: Manhattan’s New Green Space Was J.P. Morgan’s Side Yard
description: The Morgan Library & Museum celebrates the restoration of a McKim building and unveils a garden with classical sculptures from the financier’s collection.
content: In 1908, an unnamed correspondent for The Times of London wrote the first public account of the two-year-old library of the financier J. Pierpont Morgan, next to his home just east of Madison Avenue on 36th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: America’s Most Luxurious Butter Lives to Churn Another Day
description: Animal Farm Creamery, one of the most highly regarded small dairies in America, was nearly lost. Then, a young couple down the road stepped in.
content: SHOREHAM, Vt. — In a wooden barn perched on a grassy hill, some of the most celebrated cows in the dairy business — the bovine royal family of American fancy butter — sampled hay in their new abode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Pleads Guilty to Selling $2.7 Million Worth of Unregistered Covid Pesticide
description: Paul Andrecola, a 63-year-old New Jersey chemist, sold pesticides that had not been registered with the Environmental Protection Agency. Some of his customers were federal agencies.
content: A New Jersey man admitted in federal court on Thursday to illegally selling $2.7 million worth of pesticides that he falsely claimed had been registered with the Environmental Protection Agency as effective safeguards against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liesl Schillinger
title: Two Men of the Jungle Meet in Herzog’s First Novel
description: In “The Twilight World,” the filmmaker Werner Herzog vividly reconstructs the personal war of Hiroo Onoda, who stayed in the jungle for years after World War II ended.
content: Twenty-five years ago in Tokyo, where he had come to direct the world premiere of the opera “Chushingura,” the German filmmaker Werner Herzog received an enviable invitation. At a dinner of the cast and crew, the opera’s composer greeted Herzog with the thrilling news that the emperor of Japan would welcome a private audience with him. “My goodness, I have no idea what I would talk about with the emperor,” Herzog responded. The room froze. “I wish to this day that the earth had swallowed me up,” Herzog recalls dramatically in his first novel, “The Twilight World” — a book in which, his epigraph explains, “most details are factually correct; some are not.” When a guest broke the silence to ask if there was anyone in Japan he would, in fact, like to meet, Herzog answered: “Onoda.” He elaborated: “Hiroo Onoda.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Low Pay Is Thinning Staff at Public Defender Offices, Straining Those Who Stay
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 10, 2022.
content: “Budgets are values. If you’re worried about staffing N.Y.P.D. and staffing up corrections, but you’re not worried about staffing up the public defenders, you’ve got a value problem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Dining Out This Summer
description: Professional eaters give advice.
content: Summer is on the horizon and the urge to spend lazy evenings dining with friends on a sunny terrace is getting stronger. At the same time, virus cases are ticking up in many areas of the U.S., complicating the restaurant experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Feeding a Hotter Planet
description: Hunger is rising again even though we produce enough food. As the planet warms, it’s crucial to fix a broken system.
content: The world faces a frightening hunger crisis. Climate change makes it worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Rents climbed, a pain for tenants and policymakers alike.
description: Housing costs make up a big part of the overall inflation index, so they are keeping pressure on prices overall.
content: The cost of renting an apartment or home is climbing quickly, keeping inflation high and making life tougher for households on a tight budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Our Racial Reckoning Could Have Come Sooner. What Made 2020 Different?
description: The murder of George Floyd, a pandemic and social media released a storm.
content: Why was there an all-encompassing racial reckoning in this country starting in the spring of 2020? And why then? Examining that question reminds us that history is driven — by general trends classifiable as progress or decline — but also just happens. Specifically, chance factors, what historians sometimes call “contingency,” have greater effects than we are always inclined to notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and Jeff Sommer
title: Markets Recoil as Inflation Report Raises Stakes for Fed
description: The data suggested that policymakers would need to take aggressive steps to cool the economy, spooking investors.
content: Stubbornly high inflation has loomed over the stock market for months, but some investors had started to think that the worst was over. They cited scattered signs of moderation in price increases and a belief that policymakers could rein them in without sinking the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How Inflation May Change Where You Put Your Cash
description: At last, interest rates for money market funds have started to rise. But inflation means that in real terms, you’re still losing money.
content: The stock market hasn’t provided much joy, bonds have been a source of considerable pain and inflation is troubling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Why Monetary Policy Has Gotten So Hard
description: If you aren’t taking risks, you aren’t doing your job.
content: Today’s newsletter isn’t about what the Federal Reserve or its counterpart the European Central Bank should be doing. I have views, of course: For what it’s worth, I think the Fed is getting it roughly right and the E.C.B. is overreacting. But that’s a debate both huge and inconclusive; in fact, it may never be resolved, since people are so good at convincing themselves that they were right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Et Tu, Ivanka?
description: Even some of the president’s closest allies knew his Big Lie was a lie. But it’s the Jan. 6 congressional committee bringing the truth to light.
content: It turns out that not even Donald Trump’s daughter Ivanka bought into the former president’s toxic fantasies about the 2020 election having been stolen from him. She came to understand pretty quickly after the election that there was no evidence of a plot by Democrats, accepting the assessment of Bill Barr, Mr. Trump’s attorney general at the time, that the game had not been rigged. Mr. Trump had lost, and all the wild claims to the contrary, as Mr. Barr says he told Mr. Trump, were “bullshit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Miriam Jordan and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Biden, Looking for Unity, Faces Criticism From Latin American Leaders
description: The U.S. president called for concrete commitments on several major issues, but other leaders said the United States is doing too little to meet the moment.
content: LOS ANGELES — President Biden on Thursday promised aggressive new leadership to confront economic despair and mass migration in Latin America, but his pledge was met with skepticism from the leaders in the region, who said the United States is doing too little to meet the grim moment of a global crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Liberal Are the Movies?: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Cool Cukes, Alluring Avocado
description: Hetty McKinnon’s easy, earthy recipe contrasts crunch with creaminess.
content: For much of my life, I thought I didn’t like cucumbers. I liked sour pickles and Sichuan-style smashed cucumbers, but in most other settings — especially bad renditions of Greek salad — cucumbers struck me as watery, slippery filler, the honeydew of the savory salad world. (I stand by my dislike of honeydew.) Why would you dunk a cucumber spear in dip when you could choose a carrot? Or a radish? Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: You’re Never Too Young for a Roth I.R.A.
description: But there are rules around opening one for a child. First: The child must have earned income.
content: Has your teenager landed a summer job? Good! Now, consider putting your child’s earnings to work long term by opening a Roth individual retirement account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrett M. Graff
title: Three Critical Lessons of the Watergate Hearings That the Jan. 6 Committee Should Learn
description: How do you take a complex, amorphous series of events, with a wide, confusing cast of characters, and translate it to the American people?
content: The Jan. 6 committee kicked off Thursday night with a powerful first hearing, complete with compelling witnesses, video clips of depositions and stunning footage of the violence that unfolded at the Capitol as Congress tried to certify the electoral vote. It came almost a half-century after the nation was captivated by a summer’s worth of Senate Watergate hearings — a cinematic 1973 drama packed with eye-opening revelations that ultimately helped unravel Richard Nixon’s presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Kushner said he thought White House counsel was ‘whining’ when he spoke of resigning.
description: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, was featured prominently in videotaped testimony saying that he was engrossed in pushing through dozens of pardons at the end of the administration and dismissed threats of resigning by the White House counsel as “whining.”
content: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, was featured prominently in videotaped testimony saying that he was engrossed in pushing through dozens of pardons at the end of the administration and dismissed threats of resigning by the White House counsel as “whining.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Three Characters at the Heart of an Unsettling Jan. 6 Narrative
description: The House committee built the story it laid out around Donald Trump, the Proud Boys and a Capitol Police officer, drawing clear contrasts along the way.
content: At the heart of the Jan. 6 committee’s presentation Thursday night was a gripping story with a sprawling cast of characters, but only three main players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Steven Knight Isn’t Ready for ‘Peaky Blinders’ to End
description: The cult British show’s final season is now on Netflix, but its creator has plans for a spinoff movie and says he wants to follow the Shelby family into the 1940s and ’50s.
content: LONDON — Steven Knight knew something special was happening around “Peaky Blinders,” his TV crime drama, a few years ago, when the rapper Snoop Dogg asked to talk with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Bradley
title: U.K. Officials Won’t Investigate Political Donation Flagged for Russian Origins
description: A bank alert had said a $630,225 Conservative Party donation originated in a Russian account. The authorities say there’s no evidence that a crime was committed.
